text: Hey guys! We are performing a multivariate test on one of the CTAs on our site, only changing the label of the CTA. We noticed that when you reload the page with the CTA, it shows changes the label almost every time. How does the multivariate test work? Shouldn't it show the same label every time in a session/for a user? Change on reload seems really strange IMO
custom forms api and custom JS
I think it shows at random. How many people are you expecting to reload the single page?
The CTA is in the global content (bit of a workaround, since you cant A/B test global content), so people who visit several pages might see different CTAs
gotcha! I’ve done that before. There are drawbacks, but if users only visit 3 or so pages, then it shouldn’t effect results too much. How many page views in an average session?
Ah okey! Around 3 I think, but we believe it is critical they see the same label, so we'll probably look for some other way to test this. Thank you though!

<@U7SL518D6>, back to this thread really fast, you indicate the Page Speed Insights has no effect if webp or not, but just wondering why in the report it shows it could have potential savings of KiB, can you share with me articles that explains that next-gen formats like webp does not effect the Page Insights Scores

I've considered JS and hiding properties where not needed, but hit walls where fields need to be mandatory

```I currently have a pipeline that has a lot of customer tickets.
I would like to know how many tickets I have in each column.
How many tickets do you have with each owner.

Hello, I am new here, I was wondering if anyone had experience with integrating clear care, to HubSpot. (<https://www.clearcareonline.com/>)

Hey Chris I apologize it seems I wasnt clear enough. The images ARE served in WebP. I was not at all saying webp was not more performant. I was stating that it seems to be a false positive in the recommendations. Because your images are already WebP the score is the same regardless of if the recommendation shows. The score is based on the metrics. You can have a 100 on google page speed insights but still have recommendations showing.

The recommendations are suggestions for improvements based on things they can detect in the page to help you improve the core web vitals scores, they do not themselves have point values.

The kib savings noted are likely simply taking the existing file extension and using that as the source file type and using the cumulative average Google found in % improvement for png to webp and jpg to webp. If they actually tried to convert the image it likely would error because the image is in WebP format its just using the original files extension.
